greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Characteristic cube divisor of n: cube of g = gcd(K,F), where K is the largest square root divisor of n (A000188) and F = n/(K*K) = A007913(n) is its squarefree part; g^2 divides K^2 = A008833(n) = g^2*L^2 and g divides F = gf.
comment: This is not the largest cube which divides n. It is canonical, since the decomposition n = KKgggf is unique (factors are defined above and dependent on n).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..19683
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e)=1 for even e, a(p)=1, a(p^e)=p^3 for odd e > 1. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, May 01 2002
example: If n=24, largest square divisor is 4, squarefree part is 6, g=2, a(24)=8; n=81, largest square divisor is 81, both F and g is 1, a(81)=1.
mathematica: a[n_]:=With[{sf=Times@@Power@@@({#[[1]], Mod[#[[2]], 2]}&/@FactorInteger[n])}, GCD[sf, n/sf]]; Table[a[n]^3, {n, 1, 100}] (* _Vincenzo Librandi_, Oct 08 2017 *)
program: (Scheme, with memoization-macro definec, after _Vladeta Jovovic_'s multiplicative formula)
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Aug 02 2000
